author: By Maggie Haberman and Nicholas Fandos
title: Trump’s New Lawyers Not Expected to Focus on False Election Claims in His Defense
description: While Mr. Trump has argued for it, his lawyers will instead echo the argument of many Republicans that the impeachment trial of a former president is unconstitutional.
content: The new legal team that former President Donald J. Trump has brought in for his impeachment trial next week is unlikely to focus his defense on his baseless claims of widespread election fraud and instead question whether the trial is even constitutional since he is no longer president, people close to the team said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The GameStop Rebellion
description: What began as a story about Reddit versus Wall Street has since revealed itself to be something larger. We have an explanation of what happened and what it means.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Mike Baker
title: An Emboldened Extremist Wing Flexes Its Power in a Leaderless G.O.P.
description: As more far-right Republicans take office and exercise power, party officials are promoting unity and neutrality rather than confronting dangerous messages and disinformation.
content: WASHINGTON — Knute Buehler, who led Oregon’s Republican ticket as the candidate for governor in 2018, watched with growing alarm in recent weeks as Republicans around the nation challenged the reliability of the presidential election results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: What Is GameStop, the Company, Really Worth? Does It Matter?
description: The frenzy for the troubled retailer’s stock has been a head-scratcher for the analysts who try to determine a company’s value.
content: For many years, it didn’t matter that GameStop’s stores were a little grungy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Sweet Things at ABC Home
description: Bakery by ABC Restaurants is a new retail bakery from Jean-Georges Vongerichten and the pastry chef Karen DeMasco.
content: Jean-Georges Vongerichten has just added Bakery by ABC Restaurants, a vegetarian retail bakery offering pickup and delivery, to his cluster of restaurants at ABC Carpet & Home. The pastry chef, Karen DeMasco, has assembled a Valentine’s Day chocolate cookie box ($48), with four varieties of six cookies each. She is also baking pistachio crumb babkas ($22), chocolate layer cakes ($68) and pies ($38) in three flavors: chocolate custard, apple quince and lemon meringue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: The Economy Is Improving Faster Than Expected, the U.S. Budget Office Says
description: Large sectors of the economy are adapting to the pandemic better than originally expected, and December’s economic aid package helped to increase growth, adding another twist to stimulus talks.
content: The American economy will return to its pre-pandemic size by the middle of this year, even if Congress does not approve any more federal aid for the recovery, but it will be years before everyone thrown off the job by the pandemic is able to return to work, the Congressional Budget Office projected on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: The ‘Dr. Fauci’ of the Texas Border Is Counting the Dead
description: Laredo, Texas, is enduring the country’s worst outbreak at the end of the pandemic’s deadliest month. A crusading cardiologist, leading the fight, is begging the state to close down his city.
content: LAREDO, Texas — Each day at around 6 p.m., Dr. Ricardo Cigarroa goes through the same grim ritual. He sits at his desk and counts the dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: What to Know About the Northeast Winter Storm
description: A nor’easter is expected to stall off the coast of New Jersey and may drop more than two inches of snow an hour in some parts of the region, the National Weather Service said.
content: A major winter storm is descending on the Northeast, where governors and mayors issued emergency declarations on Sunday in anticipation of heavy snow and high winds that they said were expected to lead to widespread power losses and treacherous travel conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Who’s the Front-Runner? 5 Takeaways From the First Mayoral Debate
description: Questions about the Yang campaign’s treatment of women and Citigroup’s role in the mortgage crisis created moments of friction among the New York City contenders.
content: Most mayoral debates in New York City — or anywhere, for that matter — do not get disrupted by cellphone calls. Twice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanne Theoharis
title: The Real Rosa Parks Story Is Better Than the Fairy Tale
description: The way we talk about her covers up uncomfortable truths about American racism.
content: Mug shot No. 7053 is one of the most iconic images of Rosa Parks. But the photo, often seen in museums and textbooks and on T-shirts and websites, isn’t what it seems. Though it’s regularly misattributed as such, it is not the mug shot taken at the time of Mrs. Parks’s arrest in Montgomery, Ala., on Dec. 1, 1955, after she famously refused to give up her seat on a bus to a white passenger. It was, in fact, taken when she was arrested in February 1956 after she and 88 other “boycott leaders” were indicted by the city in an attempt to end the boycott. The confusion around the image reveals Americans’ overconfidence in what we think we know about Mrs. Parks and about the civil rights movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Term Limits? Not for Vietnam’s Hard-Line Communist Leader
description: Nguyen Phu Trong, 76, was named to a third term in office as party leaders were unable to reach consensus on a successor. The reappointment may have put off a transition to more pragmatic leadership.
content: BANGKOK — Under the rules of Vietnam’s Communist Party, its chief is to step aside at age 65 or after two terms. The country’s dogmatic leader, Nguyen Phu Trong, would not qualify for reappointment on either count.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Charlie Savage
title: Trump Official’s Last-Day Deal With ICE Union Ties Biden’s Hands
description: A whistle-blower accused Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II of an abuse of power in making sweeping concessions to pro-Trump Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents.
content: WASHINGTON — A whistle-blower complaint filed on Monday said a top Trump homeland security official sought to constrain the Biden administration’s immigration agenda by agreeing to hand policy controls to the pro-Trump union representing Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman, Joseph Goldstein and Jesse McKinley
title: Sidelined by Cuomo, nine top New York State health officials have quit in recent months.
description: The deputy commissioner for public health at the New York State Health Department resigned in late summer. Soon after, the director of its bureau of communicable disease control also stepped down. So did the medical director for epidemiology. Last month, the state epidemiologist said she, too, would be leaving.
content: The deputy commissioner for public health at the New York State Health Department resigned in late summer. Soon after, the director of its bureau of communicable disease control also stepped down. So did the medical director for epidemiology. Last month, the state epidemiologist said she, too, would be leaving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Marc Wilmore, a Television Comedy Writer and Producer, Dies at 57
description: Mr. Wilmore was best known for his work on “In Living Color” and “F Is for Family.” One of his elaborate pranks led to a more than decade-long stint on “The Simpsons.”
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Your New Favorite Soup
description: Melissa Clark’s latest, a creamy potato-Cheddar soup with quick-pickled jalapeños, is easy to love.
content: Good morning. Melissa Clark has a terrific new recipe in The Times this week, for a creamy potato-Cheddar soup with quick-pickled jalapeños (above). The acidic zing of the pickled peppers is a surprise and a delight against the velvet sheen of potato and cheese, and I think if you make it tonight you may well find yourself thinking: Oh, wow, a new favorite soup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Seeking a Date but Finding Hypocrisy in ‘Hi, Are You Single?’
description: All Ryan J. Haddad wants is a boyfriend. But his pride — or is it his prospects’ prejudice? — keeps getting in the way.
content: “The first time I walked into a gay bar,” Ryan J. Haddad tells us, “the first thing I encountered was a staircase.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $975,000 Homes in California
description: A four-bedroom house with a pool in Rancho Mirage, a farmhouse on five acres in Petaluma and a one-bedroom condominium in San Francisco.
content: This house is in the Tamarisk section of Rancho Mirage, named after the Tamarisk Country Club, a golf and tennis club less than a mile away that was founded in 1952. Several other golf courses are within a five-minute drive, so the area is popular with golfers, and golf carts are as common a sight in driveways as cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Mike Baker
title: An emboldened extremist wing is flexing its power in a leaderless G.O.P.
description: With the departure of former President Donald J. Trump, the G.O.P. has become a leaderless party, with past standard-bearers changing their voter registrations, luminaries like Senator Rob Portman of Ohio retiring, and far-right extremists like Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia building a brand on a web of dangerous conspiracy theories.
content: With the departure of former President Donald J. Trump, the G.O.P. has become a leaderless party, with past standard-bearers changing their voter registrations, luminaries like Senator Rob Portman of Ohio retiring, and far-right extremists like Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia building a brand on a web of dangerous conspiracy theories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: vivacious
description: This word has appeared in 29 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Analysis: Lessons from 2009 are driving Democrats’ economic response.
description: Ten Republican senators asked President Biden on Sunday to drastically scale back his $1.9 trillion pandemic aid bill, offering a $600 billion alternative that they said could pass quickly with bipartisan support.
content: Ten Republican senators asked President Biden on Sunday to drastically scale back his $1.9 trillion pandemic aid bill, offering a $600 billion alternative that they said could pass quickly with bipartisan support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Alzheimer’s Prediction May Be Found in Writing Tests
description: IBM researchers trained artificial intelligence to pick up hints of changes in language ahead of the onset of neurological diseases.
content: Is it possible to predict who will develop Alzheimer’s disease simply by looking at writing patterns years before there are symptoms?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and John Schwartz
title: Is this storm considered a blizzard? A nor’easter?
description: Blizzard is a colloquialism that is often used when there is a significant winter storm. But certain conditions must be met for a storm to qualify as a blizzard; the distinction is not based solely on snowfall.
content: Blizzard is a colloquialism that is often used when there is a significant winter storm. But certain conditions must be met for a storm to qualify as a blizzard; the distinction is not based solely on snowfall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Tony Bennett Reveals He Has Alzheimer’s Disease
description: “He’s not the old Tony anymore,” his wife, Susan, said. “But when he sings, he’s the old Tony.”
content: Tony Bennett, the 94-year-old singer who has become a beloved interpreter of the American songbook, has been diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease, his wife, Susan, told AARP The Magazine this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. Opposition Demands Action as Building Cladding Crisis Escalates
description: The Labour Party is pressuring the government to come to the aid of homeowners living in apartments wrapped in dangerous flammable material that was the cause of the Grenfell Tower fire in 2017.
content: LONDON — Nearly four years after a fire killed 72 people as it tore through London’s Grenfell Tower — a high-rise building clad in flammable material — Britain’s opposition party is demanding that the government come to the aid of hundreds of thousands of people living in dangerous apartments and buildings with similar cladding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A second weekend of protests in Russia.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Amid heightened security concerns at the Capitol, a winter pastime is interrupted.
description: As inches of snow pile up during Washington’s biggest winter storm in two years, there is one place that won’t be seeing any snowball fights.
content: As inches of snow pile up during Washington’s biggest winter storm in two years, there is one place that won’t be seeing any snowball fights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Worker Deaths Put Big Tech in China Under Scrutiny
description: The deaths of two young employees of Pinduoduo, an e-commerce platform, have reignited longstanding concerns about working conditions at internet giants.
content: It was 1:30 a.m. just days before the new year, and the 22-year-old employee of Pinduoduo, a Chinese e-commerce company, was leaving after a long day of work. Suddenly, she clutched her stomach and collapsed. Her co-workers rushed her to a hospital, but six hours later, she died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Prestigious Istanbul University Fights Erdogan’s Reach
description: Students and professors at Bogazici University, one of Turkey’s most well-known institutions, are protesting President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s appointment of a new rector.
content: ISTANBUL — For several weeks — rain, shine, or even snow — a rebellion has been underway in one of the most hallowed establishments of Turkish academia: the campus of Bogazici University in Istanbul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Major Snowstorm Hits New York City
description: In all, 18 inches could accumulate, and wind gusts could reach 50 miles per hour. Officials advise that people stay inside and avoid travel.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: To Get on This SpaceX Flight, You Don’t Have to Be Rich, Just Lucky
description: Jared Isaacman, 37-year-old founder of Shift4 Payments, is chartering a trip to orbit and raffling a seat to a random winner to raise money for childhood cancer research.
content: A new era is opening in spaceflight, a future where anyone — at least anyone with tens of millions of dollars — can buy a rocket ride to see Earth from a couple of hundred miles up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg and Jim Rutenberg
title: Key Takeaways From Trump’s Effort to Overturn the Election
description: A Times examination of the 77 days between election and inauguration shows how a lie the former president had been grooming for years overwhelmed the Republican Party and stoked the assault on the Capitol.
content: For 77 days between the election and the inauguration, President Donald J. Trump attempted to subvert American democracy with a lie about election fraud that he had been grooming for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Effort to Include $15 Minimum Wage in Relief Bill Poses Test for Democrats
description: The measure will test their willingness and ability to use procedural maneuvers to shepherd big policy goals past entrenched Republican opposition in an evenly divided Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — As Senator Bernie Sanders, the Vermont independent, prepares to take control of the Senate Budget Committee, he is mounting an aggressive campaign ahead of what will be one of his first tests as chairman: securing the support needed to increase the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour by 2025 in a pandemic relief package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: She’s the Dancing Force Behind Nia Dennis’s Viral Gymnastics Routines
description: Bijoya Das, a former gymnast with a deep relationship to dance, is training U.C.L.A. team members to let their personality light up the mat.
content: The Bruins gymnastics team of the University of California, Los Angeles, has more than one secret weapon. Yes, there’s Nia Dennis whose floor routine, an exuberant and powerful celebration of Black culture, went viral last week. But the team also has another rising star: the choreographer Bijoya Das.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: The N.F.L.’s Flagging Effort to Hire Black Head Coaches
description: In the latest hiring cycle, Eric Bieniemy, the Kansas City Chiefs’ offensive coordinator, watched from the sideline as white peers were chosen as head coaches.
content: The N.F.L. can’t hide its Eric Bieniemy problem with poetry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naomi Zewde and Darrick Hamilton
title: What Canceling Student Debt Would Do for the Racial Wealth Gap
description: A solution to the debt crisis would help all borrowers. But it could also begin to address a history of discriminatory policies affecting Black graduates.
content: In his victory speech, Joe Biden made a promise to America’s Black community: “You’ve always had my back, and I’ll have yours.” Such a focus on racial justice is especially welcome at a time when activists have put a focus on anti-Black racism and when Black Americans are suffering disproportionately from the Covid-19 pandemic and the job losses it has created. But the sentiment needs to be backed up with prompt action.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Exxon Mobil to invest $3 billion in carbon capture and other projects to lower emissions.
description: Many climate experts have said that such carbon capture and sequestration will be critical in the fight against climate change.
content: Exxon Mobil, which has long been criticized by environmentalists and some investors and elected leaders for not doing enough to curb climate change, said on Monday it would invest $3 billion over the next five years in energy projects that lower emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Maggie Haberman
title: The cousin of a lawyer who helped defend Trump in his first impeachment is hired for the trial.
description: A House Republican staff lawyer who led President Donald J. Trump’s early defense against his first impeachment in 2019 recommended one of the lawyers who Mr. Trump hired over the weekend to represent him in his second trial, a person familiar with the decision said. The two lawyers know each other well; they are cousins.
content: A House Republican staff lawyer who led President Donald J. Trump’s early defense against his first impeachment in 2019 recommended one of the lawyers who Mr. Trump hired over the weekend to represent him in his second trial, a person familiar with the decision said. The two lawyers know each other well; they are cousins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: A Dog’s Place Is at the White House
description: A home feels different when a dog lives there. Now 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue will be different, too.
content: NASHVILLE — There are too many ways for a house to be empty when a dog doesn’t live there. A hundred ways. A thousand ways. A crumb dropped or a splatter spilled is just a mess to clean up, not a wonderful surprise for a creature who lives in open anticipation of wonder. A door is just the way into an empty house, not the entrance to a party where everyone has been waiting for you far longer than they could bear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Watchdogs Appointed by Trump Pose Dilemma for Biden
description: Removing inspectors general installed by the former president under a political cloud could have the consequence of further eroding good-government norms.
content: WASHINGTON — Even as the Biden administration has moved aggressively to undo Donald J. Trump’s policies and dislodge his loyalists from positions on boards and civil-service jobs, it has hesitated on a related choice: whether to remove two inspectors general appointed by Mr. Trump under a storm of partisan controversy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Rachel Shorey
title: Trump’s Sleight of Hand: Shouting Fraud, Pocketing Donors’ Cash for Future
description: With breathless, often misleading appeals, the former president promised small donors that he was using the money to fight the election results, but in fact stored much of it for future use.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump and the Republican Party leveraged false claims of voter fraud and promises to overturn the election to raise more than a quarter-billion dollars in November and December as hundreds of thousands of trusting supporters listened and opened their wallets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: The 10 Best Titles Leaving Netflix This Month
description: An array of great movies and TV shows are leaving for U.S. subscribers by February’s end. It’s a short month; stream these while you can.
content: This month’s batch of Netflix exoduses feature some big names — Eastwood, Scorsese, Soderbergh, Verhoeven — and a variety of pleasures, from cop comedy to gangster sprawl to historical documentary, as well as the erotic thriller that launched a thousand imitators (and parodies).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Caution and Distrust Go Hand in Hand as M.L.B. Negotiates a New Season
description: The players’ union rejected a proposal for a delayed, compressed schedule, saying it would “instead continue preparations for an on-time start to the 2021 season.”
content: The 2020 Major League Baseball season began on July 23, a day in which there were just over 70,000 new coronavirus cases reported in the United States. On Friday, when M.L.B. presented a proposal to the players’ union to push back the start of the 2021 season by roughly a month — and shave eight games off each team’s schedule — more than 165,000 new cases were reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley
title: $500 Billion in Aid to Small Businesses: How Much Did It Help?
description: Some economists say the Paycheck Protection Program has not proved as useful as other aid. The debate could sway the new administration’s plans.
content: As Democrats and Republicans spent months last fall arguing over how to rescue the economy, one provision drew widespread support from lawmakers: reviving the Paycheck Protection Program, the government’s marquee effort to help small businesses weather the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Marcus Samuelsson Talks Food at the Whitney
description: The chef joins the museum’s director, Adam D. Weinberg, for two discussions about the intersection of food and culture.
content: Next week, the chef Marcus Samuelsson and Adam D. Weinberg, the director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, will give a free talk about art and food, with a focus on Black artists and chefs, and how museums and restaurants are coping with the pandemic. Museum members will get a chance to hear more from Mr. Samuelsson and Mr. Weinberg on Feb. 26 at 5 p.m., during a more in-depth discussion of the subject, with a focus on recipes and a cooking demonstration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Dustin Diamond, Actor on ‘Saved by the Bell,’ Dies at 44
description: Mr. Diamond played Screech on the NBC high school sitcom, but struggled to find work and reconcile with cast members in the decades after the show ended.
content: Dustin Diamond, the former child actor who found fame on the enduring NBC Saturday morning sitcom “Saved by the Bell” but struggled to find work in later years, died on Monday in Florida. He was 44.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kazin
title: The 1776 Follies
description: Trump’s defunct commission on American history was unintentionally revealing.
content: What is the meaning of American history? According to the 1776 report, rushed out by a presidential commission of the same name just two days before Donald Trump left office (and terminated by President Biden on his first day), it begins and ends with the “fundamental truths” expressed in the nation’s founding documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: Foo Fighters Wanted to Rule Rock. 25 Years Later, They’re Still Roaring.
description: Dave Grohl and his bandmates are called upon whenever rock music with joy and gravitas is required. Now they’re releasing an album with a twist.
content: Dave Grohl has done so much throughout his career — drummed for Nirvana, arguably the biggest band of its generation; led Foo Fighters, one of the most successful acts of the last three decades; sold out Wembley Stadium, twice; played on the White House lawn; interviewed the sitting president of the United States; broke his leg during a show and finished the show with the broken leg; entered the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, with another induction likely on the way; recorded with both living Beatles; appeared on “The Muppets,” also twice — that when you ask him what’s left, he takes a moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Football Practices Pose More Concussion Risk Than Games, Study Suggests
description: The report will fuel the longstanding debate about safety in college football, but changes do not appear to be imminent.
content: College football players sustained far more concussions during practices than they did in games, medical researchers reported on Monday, a finding certain to add to the yearslong debate about regulating training regimens across the sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Shelby Knowles
title: Relief Proposals, U.S. Economy, Alzheimer’s: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: BioNTech promises 75 million additional vaccine doses for the E.U.
description: BERLIN — As Germany’s leaders gather in Berlin to discuss the lagging vaccinations in the country and across the European Union, the bloc got some good news Monday morning when the pharmaceutical company BioNTech announced that it would make 75 million extra doses available in coming months.
content: BERLIN — As Germany’s leaders gather in Berlin to discuss the lagging vaccinations in the country and across the European Union, the bloc got some good news Monday morning when the pharmaceutical company BioNTech announced that it would make 75 million extra doses available in coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson and Matt Phillips
title: Silver Rises With Hype It’s the Next GameStop, but a Backlash Mutes Gains
description: The precious metal jumped 11.5 percent to its highest level in eight years, then gave up some of its gains as some online investors smelled a trap.
content: After the frantic price swings of companies like GameStop and AMC Entertainment tantalized the financial world last week, everyone wondered what the army of internet investors would set its sights on next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman, Joseph Goldstein and Jesse McKinley
title: 9 Top N.Y. Health Officials Have Quit as Cuomo Scorns Expertise
description: “When I say ‘experts’ in air quotes, it sounds like I’m saying I don’t really trust the experts,” Gov. Andrew Cuomo said of pandemic policies. “Because I don’t.”
content: The deputy commissioner for public health at the New York State Health Department resigned in late summer. Soon after, the director of its bureau of communicable disease control also stepped down. So did the medical director for epidemiology. Last month, the state epidemiologist said she, too, would be leaving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: How Have You Used Our Student Editorials as Mentor Texts? An Invitation to Teachers and Students
description: Ahead of our popular annual Student Editorial Contest, we want to hear how you’ve taught — or learned — with the work of our winners.
content: Kabby Hong, an English teacher in Wisconsin, shows his students how essays like “In Three and a Half Hours, an Alarm Will Go Off,” a 2015 contest winner, not only make a tight argument, but do so with voice and style. He says the varied verbs in the first paragraph alone — “drag,” “plop” and “dive” — inspire his students to be more thoughtful about their own word choices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
title: Not yet desperate, Japan and South Korea plod toward vaccinations.
description: Japan’s biggest cities are under a state of emergency as coronavirus deaths rise, even while the country tries to convince the world it can safely hold the Summer Olympics. South Korea is prohibiting gatherings of five or more people to keep a recent surge under control. Hong Kong imposed stringent lockdowns on some of its poorest neighborhoods to stop an uptick.
content: Japan’s biggest cities are under a state of emergency as coronavirus deaths rise, even while the country tries to convince the world it can safely hold the Summer Olympics. South Korea is prohibiting gatherings of five or more people to keep a recent surge under control. Hong Kong imposed stringent lockdowns on some of its poorest neighborhoods to stop an uptick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: A W.H.O. team looks for clues about the origins of the virus in Wuhan.
description: A team of World Health Organization experts investigating the origin of the pandemic has started its mission in the Chinese city of Wuhan by visiting some of the places first hit by the coronavirus.
content: A team of World Health Organization experts investigating the origin of the pandemic has started its mission in the Chinese city of Wuhan by visiting some of the places first hit by the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: The warming Arctic plays a role in storms like the one hitting the Northeast.
description: The New York City area took a pounding from the latest nor’easter, with predictions of snow depths that have only grown in recent days.
content: The New York City area took a pounding from the latest nor’easter, with predictions of snow depths that have only grown in recent days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar
title: India’s Modest Budget Signals Modi’s Limited Options
description: Health care and infrastructure spending received significant increases, but fears about inflation could hold back efforts to get the economy surging again.
content: NEW DELHI — The world’s biggest economies are trying to borrow and spend their way out of the pandemic, from the European Union’s $900 billion stimulus package to President Biden’s proposed $1.9 trillion rescue plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: Rochester Officers Suspended After Pepper-Spraying of 9-Year-Old Girl
description: The incident, captured on body-camera footage, renewed scrutiny of a department whose officers had placed a hood on Daniel Prude, a Black man, before he died from suffocation.
content: The police department in Rochester, N.Y., released body-camera footage on Sunday that showed a 9-year-old girl being handcuffed and pepper-sprayed by police officers who had responded to a family disturbance call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The N.B.A. Misses Klay Thompson
description: Thompson, the Golden State Warriors’ All-Star guard, is a great shooter, for sure. But his absence, for a second consecutive season because of injury, leaves a hole that goes beyond basketball.
content: Klay Thompson could have re-entered the game for the Golden State Warriors, but he knew his work was done. It was Jan. 23, 2015, and Thompson had spent the third quarter scoring a record 37 points without missing a shot against the Sacramento Kings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Demetrios Ioannou
title: Glimpses of an Ancient Fire-Walking Ritual in Northern Greece
description: Each May in the small Greek village of Lagadas, a group of celebrants upholds a three-day tradition that incorporates a range of age-old rites.
content: The room was dimly lit, illuminated only by a weak yellow light bulb and the flames from the fireplace. A small group of men and women, clutching the holy icons of Greek Orthodox saints, was dancing and twirling around the floor under the sound of the instruments: a Thracian lyre, a gaida, a tambourine. The dancers, surrendering to the music, had their eyes closed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Test for Biden: How Boldly to Disavow Trump’s Agenda
description: New administrations are generally cautious about changing their predecessors’ legal positions. But this time may be different.
content: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. was annoyed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Survey Says: Never Tweet
description: The tensions in newsrooms over reporters’ social media presence are not just about politics.
content: David Carr, the legendary Timesman who made this column a destination, told me back in 2012 that he kept a “helicopter on the roof” of The New York Times Building in case he needed to escape. After all, he had been taking shots at media moguls, including, occasionally, his own bosses. That helicopter, he said, was his Twitter account, and it gave him the power, if needed, to flee The Times and take his followers — more than 300,000 when he died in 2015.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: One Case, Total Lockdown: Australia’s Lessons for a Pandemic World
description: The country’s short, sharp responses have repeatedly subdued the virus and allowed a return to near normalcy. Now its model is being applied to Perth, its fourth-largest city.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — One case. One young security guard at a quarantine hotel who tested positive for the coronavirus and experienced minor symptoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Making Nice With Canada
description: The Biden administration is working to recalibrate the relations between neighbors.
content: As with so much else that President Biden has done during his first days in office, a simple act of courtesy — a phone call to Canada’s prime minister, Justin Trudeau, and a promise to get together soon — is in itself viewed as a major and welcome break with the Trump era. But being friends again, Canadians have been quickly reminded, does not cure all ills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Sundance Diary, Part 4: Contending With Snow and Tech Support
description: The New York weather adds a Park City ambience, but watching online from home presents un-festival-like obstacles.
content: A.O. Scott, our critic at large, is keeping a diary as he “attends” the virtual Sundance Film Festival, which runs through Wednesday. Read previous entries here and here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A hiccup in one country can become a tragedy for everyone.
content: More than 90 million people around the world have received a coronavirus vaccine outside of clinical trials — but only 25 people total have in all of sub-Saharan Africa, a region of about one billion people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Sibongile Khumalo, South Africa’s ‘First Lady of Song,’ Dies at 63
description: Proficient across a range of genres, she had the hall-filling power of an operatic mezzo-soprano and the directness of a pop singer.
content: Sibongile Khumalo, a virtuoso vocalist whose ease of motion between opera, jazz and South African popular music made her a symbol of the country’s new social order after the end of apartheid, died on Thursday. She was 63.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Raise Your Hand if You Were Expecting Biden to Be a Revolutionary
description: The president has been much more left-wing out of the gate than many predicted. What comes next?
content: Gail Collins: Bret, the winter weather and pandemic panic are so depressing, let’s start today out with a cheerful thought. Just toss me one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: Science of the storm: Rising Arctic temperatures bring wild weather around the world.
description: This week’s winter storm is part of a pattern caused by disturbances to the upper-atmosphere phenomena known as the polar vortex that can send icy blasts from the Arctic into the middle latitudes, chilling Europe, Asia and parts of North America. The disturbance and its effects have persisted for an unusually long time this year, said Jennifer Francis, a senior scientist at the Woodwell Climate Research Center, with two disruptions of the polar vortex so far this year and, potentially, a third on the way.
content: This week’s winter storm is part of a pattern caused by disturbances to the upper-atmosphere phenomena known as the polar vortex that can send icy blasts from the Arctic into the middle latitudes, chilling Europe, Asia and parts of North America. The disturbance and its effects have persisted for an unusually long time this year, said Jennifer Francis, a senior scientist at the Woodwell Climate Research Center, with two disruptions of the polar vortex so far this year and, potentially, a third on the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Our Eighth Annual Student Editorial Contest
description: We invite middle school and high school students to write opinion pieces on the issues that matter to them. Contest dates: Feb. 23 to April 13.
content: Sign up now for our free Feb. 11 webinar about this year’s contest, Teaching Argumentative Writing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger, Quoctrung Bui and Alicia Parlapiano
title: The Government Agencies That Became Smaller, and Unhappier, Under Trump
description: The total federal civilian work force is slightly larger than four years ago, as a few agencies grew even as others shrank. In some places, morale also took a hit.
content: The federal government that Donald J. Trump inherited was aging. The Civil Service system hadn’t been updated in decades. Many workers were nearing retirement. The computers were old, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘A Look at Past Vaccine Drives: Smallpox, Polio and the Swine Flu’
description: In this lesson, students will explore vaccination campaigns of the past two centuries. Then, based on their findings, they will make recommendations to President Biden on how to improve the current vaccine rollout.
content: Featured Article: “A Look at Past Vaccine Drives: Smallpox, Polio and the Swine Flu” by Jenny Gross
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: How Climate Change May Affect Your Health
description: No matter where you live or how high your socioeconomic status, climate change can endanger your health, both physical and mental, now and in the future.
content: Melting ice caps, warmer oceans, intense storms, heat waves, droughts, floods and wildfires — all these well-documented effects of climate change may seem too remote to many people to prompt them to adopt behaviors that can slow the warming of the planet. Unless your neighborhood was destroyed by a severe hurricane or raging wildfire, you might think such disasters happen only to other people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Food Course for Home-Schooling
description: Spoons Across America has created a nine-class Food Exploration Project, suitable for students ages 8 to 11.
content: Spoons Across America — founded 19 years ago to enhance children’s understanding of cooking and health — has arranged for chefs and food professionals to visit New York City classrooms for interactive teaching sessions. This year, with the reduction and often elimination of in-person schooling, the nonprofit organization has created in-home courses for children to complete with their parents. The Food Exploration Project, suitable for children ages 8 to 11 nationwide, covers elements of taste, seasonal food, nutrition labels, healthy snacking and more, in nine sessions, each about 45 minutes to an hour long. The kit ($30) includes a guide for parents, an activity journal for the child, a child’s knife and an apron. Equipment for additional children is $10 each. There are also two free courses issuing new material twice a month, one called Food Explorers Club (for children ages 8 to 11) and a series of food-related story book segments (for children ages 6 to 7), both offering video sessions with printable materials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Biden Faces Pressure to Make Amends on Family Separation
description: Restitution, mental health services and legal permanent residency are among the demands for compensation to families harmed by the Trump-era border policy.
content: When Joselaine Cordeiro arrived at the U.S. border in 2017, she spent seven months in immigration detention in Texas while her 14-year-old son, James, languished in a shelter in Chicago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kareem Abdul-Jabbar
title: We Should Let Some N.B.A. Players Jump the Vaccine Queue
description: Like other celebrities, basketball stars can help build trust in taking the shot.
content: Last month, Arnold Schwarzenegger and I separately got our first Covid-19 vaccinations on camera, with the hope that we would encourage people who were fearful of the vaccines to reconsider. We are both 73 years old (though I clearly look much younger) and have underlying health conditions, so we didn’t use our celebrity status to jump lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Alan Yuhas
title: Jack Palladino, 76, Hard-Charging Private Investigator, Dies After ‘Brutal Attack’
description: Mr. Palladino, a private investigator who had worked for Bill Clinton and other famous clients, died four days after he sustained a severe head injury in an attempted robbery, the authorities said.
content: Jack Palladino, a San Francisco private investigator with a reputation for bare-knuckle tactics who helped Bill Clinton, Harvey Weinstein, R. Kelly and other famous clients face down scandals, died on Monday at San Francisco General Hospital. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and William K. Rashbaum
title: Trump Names Two Members of Impeachment Defense Team
description: The announcement came a day after he parted ways with five lawyers, and with his trial looming next week.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday named two lawyers who will represent him in his coming impeachment trial in the Senate, a day after he parted ways with five members of his initial team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: What Is GameStop Really Worth?
description: Believe it or not, there are real-world financials to consider.
content: In all the recent market mania, it might be easy to forget that there’s an actual company at the center of the frenzy. Here’s a quick look at the real-world prospects for GameStop, which begins the week with a market cap of more than $20 billion, up from $1 billion at the start of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Willyard
title: Had Covid? You May Need Only One Dose of Vaccine, Study Suggests
description: People who have already been sick with Covid-19 should still be vaccinated, experts say, but they may experience intense side effects even after one dose.
content: Shannon Romano, a molecular biologist, came down with Covid late last March, about a week after she and her colleagues shut down their lab at Mount Sinai Hospital. A debilitating headache came first, followed by a fever that kept rising, and then excruciating body aches. “I couldn’t sleep. I couldn’t move,” she said. “Every one of my joints just hurt inside.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Feb. 1, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 1, 2021.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 1, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian and Kevin Armstrong
title: Why Some Suburban Businesses Are Thriving During the Pandemic
description: A new crop of customers — people who once commuted to the city but now work from home — is helping some businesses stay afloat.
content: Two weeks after the pandemic’s first lockdowns began in March, officials in the borough of Westwood, N.J., came together to plan for a huge economic crisis — one the World Bank predicted would turn into “the deepest recession since the Second World War.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: On ‘I Hate Suzie,’ Sexual Freedom Is a Fantasy
description: This HBO Max comedy, along with shows like “I May Destroy You” and “Sex Education,” suggests that female sexuality and desire is always subject to the intrusion of social norms and expectations.
content: In “Shame,” the fourth episode of “I Hate Suzie” on HBO Max, the protagonist, Suzie Pickles (Billie Piper), a pop star-turned-actress who’s caught in a public sex scandal, masturbates — for almost the entire episode. Or, rather, she tries to masturbate, but the act isn’t easy; it’s a labor of equal parts determination and frustration, like a frequently benched player hobbling onto the field, already lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: The Chinese police arrest more than 80 people suspected of manufacturing fake vaccines.
description: The police in China have broken up a counterfeiting ring that they say manufactured and sold more than 3,000 fake coronavirus vaccines across the country, Xinhua, China’s state-run news agency, reported on Monday.
content: The police in China have broken up a counterfeiting ring that they say manufactured and sold more than 3,000 fake coronavirus vaccines across the country, Xinhua, China’s state-run news agency, reported on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro, Erica L. Green and Juliana Kim
title: Missing in School Reopening Plans: Black Families’ Trust
description: Deep-seated mistrust among Black families toward their public school districts is holding back school reopening, even as Black children suffer inordinately from remote learning.
content: For Farah Despeignes, the choice of whether to send her children back to New York City classrooms as the coronavirus pandemic raged on last fall was no choice at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Severe Punishment Awaits Protesters in Russia, Kremlin Says
description: The authorities said some protesters at the demonstrations calling for the release of the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny could be charged with serious offenses carrying prison sentences.
content: MOSCOW — A day after protests swept across Russia in support of a jailed opposition leader, the authorities said Monday that some participants face harsh punishment, including spells in the prison system once known as the gulag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter, Matt Phillips and Peter Eavis
title: How the Stock Market’s Relentless Rise Saved Companies
description: When the pandemic hit, banks cut credit to businesses that suddenly looked risky. Investors happily stepped in, buying their stocks and bonds.
content: Last spring, just as Denny’s was shutting down its nationwide chain of 24-hour diners for weeks of pandemic-induced lockdowns, its lenders were warning it to quickly pay down its debt — or else. With banks demanding prohibitively high interest rates, Denny’s leaders turned to the last clean, well-lighted place in corporate America: the stock market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: 20 Inches of Snow Could Fall on a City Already Quieted by the Pandemic
description: New York found itself in the midst of a nor’easter that was on track to be one of the city’s heaviest storms ever.
content: In winters past, the nor’easter that greeted the New York City region on Monday would have felt like a grim menace: a massive snowfall guaranteed to snarl commutes, close schools and darken the moods of wet New Yorkers forced to trudge along snowy sidewalks and cram onto wet subways at the start of the workweek.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Ayala
title: The Biggest W.N.B.A. Free-Agency Moves
description: Candace Parker is not the only one leaving Los Angeles, but Diana Taurasi is staying in Phoenix. W.N.B.A. free agency kicked off Monday with a shuffling of stars.
content: A landmark collective bargaining agreement before last season increased top-tier W.N.B.A. salaries to $215,000 from about $117,500. But though the new pay scale was in effect ahead of the 2020 season in Florida, it’s only this year that a number of the league’s biggest stars are unrestricted free agents and in a position to cash in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian Friedman
title: Robinhood pares its list of companies with trading restrictions to 8 from 50.
description: Robinhood, the stock platform that put restraints on trading of shares like the video game retailer GameStop and the movie theater chain AMC after a frenzy of buying and selling last week, has decreased the number of companies with trading restrictions to eight from 50, according to an update on its website.
content: Robinhood, the stock platform that put restraints on trading of shares like the video game retailer GameStop and the movie theater chain AMC after a frenzy of buying and selling last week, has decreased the number of companies with trading restrictions to eight from 50, according to an update on its website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Making the Most of Their Terrace
description: During the pandemic, one couple’s outdoor space has served as a living and dining room, kitchen, art and music studio, office, storage unit and gym.
content: The large terrace is what sold Tess Lepore and Kevin Kuh on their Upper West Side one-bedroom, but for the first few years, it didn’t get all that much use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Biden’s Approval Rating Is Trump’s in Reverse
description: Support from a slim majority might be all President Biden can expect — and maybe it’s all he needs.
content: President Biden entered the White House last month with a broadly positive approval rating — but well shy of the two-thirds of Americans who expressed support for his former boss, Barack Obama, when he took office 12 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah B. Solomon
title: Gensler Faces Big Challenge in Tackling GameStop’s Wild Ride
description: There is broad agreement that the capital markets have been distorted but less consensus on what, if anything, the S.E.C. should do about it.
content: WASHINGTON — During his last regulatory stint in Washington, Gary Gensler focused on reining in big Wall Street players that he believed were manipulating markets and assuming huge financial positions to the detriment of other investors.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The S.E.C.’s chief-to-be faces a challenge in a post-GameStop Wall Street.
description: The recent surge in GameStop’s stock — propelled by individual investors who banded together on Reddit — has put new pressure on the Biden administration’s pick for the top job at the Securities and Exchange Commission, Gary Gensler.
content: The recent surge in GameStop’s stock — propelled by individual investors who banded together on Reddit — has put new pressure on the Biden administration’s pick for the top job at the Securities and Exchange Commission, Gary Gensler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: Now’s the Time for Homemade Dumplings
description: For Lunar New Year, shape savory and sweet Chinese dumplings at home.
content: If there’s one occasion to prepare dumplings from scratch, wrappers and all, it’s the Lunar New Year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: What we know about Myanmar’s coup.
content: During early morning raids on Monday, Myanmar’s civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, was detained along with her top lieutenants. A military television network announced a one-year state of emergency with full authority transferred to the army chief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Kitamura
title: ‘Fake Accounts’ Examines the Alluring Trap of Our Online Personas
description: “Fake Accounts,” Lauren Oyler’s debut novel, considers how social media has reconfigured our behavior, relationships and how we think of ourselves.
content: FAKE ACCOUNTSBy Lauren Oyler
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Russell Goldman
title: Myanmar’s Coup, Explained
description: The coup returns the country to full military rule after a short span of quasi-democracy. Here is what we know.
content: The military of Myanmar overthrew the country’s fragile democratic government in a coup d’état on Monday, arresting civilian leaders, shutting off the internet and cutting off flights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘9to5: The Story of a Movement’ and ‘The Equalizer’
description: A new documentary on PBS looks at the roots of a women’s rights organization. And Queen Latifah stars in a reboot of “The Equalizer” on CBS.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Feb. 1-7. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Melena Ryzik
title: Evan Rachel Wood Accuses Marilyn Manson of Abuse
description: “He started grooming me when I was a teenager and horrifically abused me for years,” Ms. Wood, said on Instagram. Hours later Mr. Manson’s label dropped him.
content: The actor and singer Evan Rachel Wood, who has spoken publicly for years about being a survivor of sexual and physical violence, said on Monday that she had been abused by the rock musician Marilyn Manson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Morgan Wallen’s ‘Dangerous’ Earns a Third Week at No. 1
description: The Nashville star’s LP is the first country album since Taylor Swift’s “Red” to top the Billboard 200 for three weeks.
content: The country singer and songwriter Morgan Wallen has the No. 1 album for a third week in a row, the first time in eight years that a country LP has pulled a hat trick at the top of the Billboard album chart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar and Shannon Doyne
title: Should All Young People Learn How to Invest in the Stock Market?
description: GameStop stock has gone through the roof. What are the lessons, if any, to be learned for students, teachers and parents?
content: In January, company stock for the video game retailer GameStop soared 1,700 percent. The stock isn’t rising because the company is doing well; in fact, GameStop stores are struggling because many video gamers are buying their games online, especially during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma and Sameer Yasir
title: Nepal Seeks to Ban 2 Climbers It Says Faked Everest Summit
description: The Indian climbers submitted doctored photos appearing to show them atop the world’s tallest peak, Nepal says. Fake claims of Everest climbs have become common.
content: KATHMANDU, Nepal — The pictures seemed to show them at the top of the world, the summit of Mount Everest, and tourism officials in Nepal presented the two climbers with coveted certificates stating they had reached the world’s highest peak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Jim Tankersley
title: Republicans Pitch Biden on Smaller Aid Plan as Democrats Prepare to Act Alone
description: The president met at the White House with Republican senators seeking a much smaller stimulus plan, but congressional Democrats pressed forward to force through his $1.9 trillion measure, if necessary.
content: WASHINGTON — A coalition of 10 Republican senators took a stimulus counterproposal to the White House on Monday evening, urging President Biden to scale back his ambitions for a sweeping $1.9 trillion pandemic aid package in favor of a plan less than one-third the size that they argued could garner the bipartisan consensus the new president has said he is seeking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Kreda
title: Rangers Send Tony DeAngelo to Practice Unit
description: DeAngelo, a 25-year-old defenseman, signed a contract extension in October, but the Rangers waived him on Sunday.
content: Tony DeAngelo was sent to the Rangers’ practice unit on Monday, one day after the team waived the high-priced defenseman, who was on the ice as his team surrendered four goals in a 5-4 overtime loss on Saturday to the Pittsburgh Penguins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Message in a Chocolate Box
description: Truffolie’s Valentine’s Day chocolates carry a customizable secret message, revealed once all the pieces are eaten.
content: Here’s an invitation to consume an entire box of chocolates. Truffolie, from the chocolatier Wendy-Dawn Wintcentsen, is offering assortments of 12 or 24 heart-shaped bonbons, with an optional custom message in the box, tucked letter-by-letter under the chocolates. Of course, you could just peek and then eat or share the chocolates one at a time. There are three flavors: Carla, with dark chocolate and hazelnuts; Benni, white chocolate with assorted nuts; and Bing, white and dark chocolate with a layer of strawberry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Live Charity Event Will Reveal the Magic Behind Making Cryptic Crosswords
description: Proceeds for the Friday, Feb. 5 Zoom event will benefit The New York Times’s Neediest Cases Fund.
content: If you’ve always dreamed of learning how to make cryptic crosswords (or to “set” or “compose” them, as our fellow puzzle lovers say in the U.K.), John Halpern, one of Britain’s most prolific and popular cryptic composers, will reveal the magic behind those twisted clues, along with New York Times Crossword editor Will Shortz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro, Erica L. Green and Juliana Kim
title: One thing that’s missing in the reopening plans of U.S. schools: the trust of Black families.
description: Even as more districts reopen their buildings and President Biden joins the chorus of those saying schools can safely resume in-person education, hundreds of thousands of Black parents say they are not ready to send their children back. That reflects both the disproportionately harsh consequences the coronavirus has visited on nonwhite Americans and the profound lack of trust that Black families have in school districts, a longstanding phenomenon exacerbated by the pandemic.
content: Even as more districts reopen their buildings and President Biden joins the chorus of those saying schools can safely resume in-person education, hundreds of thousands of Black parents say they are not ready to send their children back. That reflects both the disproportionately harsh consequences the coronavirus has visited on nonwhite Americans and the profound lack of trust that Black families have in school districts, a longstanding phenomenon exacerbated by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley
title: $500 billion in aid to small businesses: How much did it help?
description: As Democrats and Republicans spent months last fall arguing over how to rescue the economy, one provision drew widespread support from lawmakers: reviving the Paycheck Protection Program, the government’s marquee effort to help small businesses weather the pandemic.
content: As Democrats and Republicans spent months last fall arguing over how to rescue the economy, one provision drew widespread support from lawmakers: reviving the Paycheck Protection Program, the government’s marquee effort to help small businesses weather the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Gondola Not Included
description: Tramezzini in the East Village has created a party box for two to transport you to Venice, at least for one meal.
content: Without breaking the budget for Valentine’s Day, two can enjoy an intimate taste of that most romantic of cities, Venice, at home. Tramezzini, a Lower East Side spot specializing in the kinds of sandwiches that Venetians enjoy with their aperitivos, tucks them in a new party box for two ($58 plus delivery). It consists of four snacks and spreads like stuffed fried olives and whipped salt cod, two kinds of small sandwiches, and wines or spritzes. Available starting Feb. 11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: 300 Questions and Images to Inspire Argument Writing
description: Recent Student Opinion and Picture Prompts, categorized by topic, to help students discover the issues that matter to them.
content: If you’ve taught argument writing with our resources in the past, you already know we ask a fresh question every day as part of our long-running Student Opinion series. Teenagers around the world are invited to visit and post their thoughts on topics including politics, medical ethics, fashion, sports and entertainment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: The ‘Dr. Fauci’ of the Texas border is counting the dead.
description: During January, the pandemic’s deadliest month, Laredo, Texas, held the bleak distinction of having one of the most severe outbreaks of any city in the United States. The death toll in the overwhelmingly Latino city of 277,000 now stands at more than 630 — including at least 126 in January alone.
content: During January, the pandemic’s deadliest month, Laredo, Texas, held the bleak distinction of having one of the most severe outbreaks of any city in the United States. The death toll in the overwhelmingly Latino city of 277,000 now stands at more than 630 — including at least 126 in January alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Popper, Michael J. de la Merced and David McCabe
title: Robinhood, Under the Gun, Raises $2.4 Billion
description: The high volume of trading by its customers, many of them egged on by social media, has put a strain on the company’s balance sheet.
content: Robinhood, the trading app at the center of a frenzy over GameStop and other stocks, raised $2.4 billion from its investors over the weekend, adding to the $1 billion cash infusion it took last week as it tries to steady its finances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Myanmar’s Coup in Pictures
description: In a matter of hours on Monday morning, Myanmar’s short-lived adoption of representative government came to an unceremonious end when the military rounded up the country’s civilian leadership and effectively declared a coup d’état.
content: In a matter of hours on Monday morning, Myanmar’s short-lived adoption of representative government came to an unceremonious end when the military rounded up the country’s civilian leadership and effectively declared a coup d’état.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: U.S. Economy Is Healing, but Budget Office Says Workers Have a Long Way to Go
description: New projections from the independent Congressional Budget Office fuel Republicans’ calls for “targeted” economic aid — and Democrats’ push to go big.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States economy will return to its pre-pandemic size by the middle of this year, even if Congress does not approve any more federal money to aid the recovery, the Congressional Budget Office said on Monday. But it will be years before everyone thrown off the job by the coronavirus is able to return to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jasper Craven
title: ‘Mind Boggling’ and ‘Deadly.’ This Is the Trump V.A.’s Racist Legacy.
description: “It needs to be cleaned up right away,” one employee said. Will Denis McDonough, Biden’s pick for V.A. secretary, help repair what’s broken?
content: In May 2014, when retired U.S. Army Medical Service Corps Officer Nuwanna Franklin moved on from the Department of Defense to an administrative position at the Veterans Affairs hospital in Dublin, Ga., she envisioned a few years of rewarding work, and then retirement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa McGirr
title: How Kamala Harris Rose — and Rose
description: “Kamala’s Way” is the story of Harris’s dramatic political career, as told by the longtime California journalist Dan Morain.
content: KAMALA’S WAYAn American LifeBy Dan Morain
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Muktita Suhartono
title: Thailand Targets Pro-Democracy Protesters in Sweeping Legal Dragnet
description: Hundreds of thousands of people marched in student-led demonstrations last year. Now some face decades behind bars.
content: BANGKOK — A 16-year-old boy is facing possible jail time for parading down a makeshift catwalk in a crop top that evoked Thailand’s king. An actress stands accused of breaking the law by cheering on and delivering spicy takeout to hungry members of the country’s protest movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Outdoor subway service in New York will resume on Tuesday morning.
description: Hundreds of stations were shut down on Monday afternoon.
content: Outdoor subway service in New York City will resume at 5 a.m. Tuesday and Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Railroad plan to start running again by 4 a.m. after suspending operations because of the storm on Monday afternoon, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s office said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Democracy Hero? Military Foil? Myanmar’s Leader Ends Up as Neither
description: The army’s detention of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi brought an abrupt end to the theory that she might strike a workable balance between civilian and military power.
content: In the years Myanmar was cowed by a military junta, people would tuck away secret photos of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, talismans of the heroine of democracy who would save her country from a fearsome army even though she was under house arrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacqueline Mroz
title: The Case of the Serial Sperm Donor
description: One man, hundreds of children and a burning question: Why?
content: In 2015, Vanessa van Ewijk, a carpenter in the Netherlands, decided that she wanted to have a child. She was 34 and single, and so, like many women, she sought out a sperm donor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Republican Economic Plan Is an Insult
description: It’s bad faith in the name of bipartisanship.
content: So 10 Republican senators are proposing an economic package that is supposed to be an alternative to President Biden’s American Rescue Plan. The proposal is only a third of the size of Biden’s plan and would in important ways cut the heart out of economic relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: I Asked Reddit’s C.E.O. About the GameStop Madness
description: Steve Huffman on the subreddit causing chaos on Wall Street.
content: Shares of GameStop shot up 400 percent last week, egged on by the Reddit forum r/WallStreetBets. The online community rallied to drive up the stock price and put the squeeze on big hedge funds who had bet against the struggling video game retailer. Reddit chief executive Steve Huffman — who calls r/WallStreetBets one of his “guilty pleasures” — described this as “the online stock-betting equivalent of, like, jumping off a cliff into a river.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Aircraft Carrier Returning Home After Long Sea Tour Watching Iran
description: The Pentagon had extended the deployment of the Nimitz in the Middle East after Iranian threats against President Donald J. Trump and U.S. troops in the region.
content: WASHINGTON — The aircraft carrier Nimitz is finally going home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: The Skin-Deep Physics of Sidewinder Snakes
description: A close-up on snake skin helped scientists work out what might help certain snakes navigate sandy surfaces.
content: When it comes to slithering, most snakes do it the same way: straight ahead. But for snakes that live in deserts, getting around can be a challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Jamie Tarses, Executive in a Hollywood Rise-and-Fall Story, Dies at 56
description: She broke barriers as a woman in the TV industry and turned out hit after hit, only to see it all fizzle under a very public spotlight.
content: LOS ANGELES — A young, female executive arrives in the men’s locker room that was broadcast television in the 1990s and snaps a few towels of her own, working with writers to shape juggernaut comedies like “Mad About You” and “Friends.” She is so good at spotting hits that she becomes, at 32, the president of entertainment at ABC, the first woman ever to serve as a network’s top programmer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
title: How Rich Hospitals Profit From Patients in Car Crashes
description: Hospitals use century-old lien laws to bypass insurers and charge patients, especially poorer ones, the full amount.
content: When Monica Smith was badly hurt in a car accident, she assumed Medicaid would cover the medical bills. Ms. Smith, 45, made sure to show her insurance card after an ambulance took her to Parkview Regional Medical Center in Fort Wayne, Ind. She spent three days in the hospital and weeks in a neck brace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Good Vaccine News
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: The news about the vaccines continues to be excellent — and the public discussion of it continues to be more negative than the facts warrant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Kits to Make Sushi and Sashimi at Home
description: The sushi restaurant MakiMaki now sells do-it-yourself meals from its Midtown location.
content: MakiMaki’s Midtown location has added a HomeChef line, for making sushi rolls and other Japanese specialties at home. The sushi roll kit comes with rice, seasoning for the rice and a rolling mat; sheets of nori; ginger, wasabi, shiso, gobo, slivered avocado, cucumber and other vegetables; and a copious quantity of high-quality frozen fish, including hamachi, yellowfin tuna and salmon. There’s more than enough to make rolls to serve four people. Instructions are included. The kit, $110 or $150, depending on the kinds of fish, comes with detailed instructions. Sashimi kits are another option, and there is a shabu-shabu kit with Wagyu beef. The fish is also sold à la carte, $9 to $45 for mostly 6-ounce portions. The kits can be delivered from West Fourth to East 88th Streets in Manhattan and are available for pickup on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Goldstein
title: The Trouble With GameStop Is That the House Still Wins
description: We can’t beat Wall Street at its own zero-sum game. But we can change the rules.
content: Last week, an alluring narrative coalesced around a band of Davids taking on the Goliaths of finance. Thousands of so-called retail traders who came together on Reddit have been using apps like Robinhood to buy stock and options of GameStop, the beleaguered video game retailer, jacking up its value some 1,700 percent last month. In the process, they’ve blown up a few hedge funds that had bet on GameStop’s failure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Abend
title: A Movie Festival for One, on a Tiny Nordic Island
description: Sweden’s Goteborg Film Festival has taken social distancing to the extreme, offering one attendee a week on a barren island, with only the competition films for company.
content: As they do at the opening of any star-studded film festival, photographers scrambled for position, training their lenses on the spot where audience members would alight. But when the first — and only — guest of honor arrived, she was clad not in a tuxedo or sparkly gown, but in jeans and an orange puffer jacket (designer unknown). There was no red carpet beneath her feet, only bare frozen ground. And instead of sauntering into a plush cinema buzzing with celebrities, she climbed into a speedboat and zipped off across the frigid water to a tiny island where she would settle in for the first premiere.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: After Rampage, Sledding Ban at the Capitol Is Another Hill to Climb
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 1, 2021.
content: “Sledding is a simple, childhood thrill. It is the least we can allow for our resilient children this winter season.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Steven Erlanger
title: Top E.U. Official Comes Under Fire in Vaccine Wars
description: Ursula von der Leyen has largely stayed away from the limelight while driving the handling of a crisis and letting subordinates take the blame.
content: BRUSSELS — On paper, Ursula von der Leyen is uniquely qualified to lead the European Union through the coronavirus crisis. A medical doctor with a masters in public health, the president of the European Commission has the backing of her native Germany as well as France, a powerful combination that catapulted her to the vaunted role less than two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Mapping Los Angeles’s Unequal Covid-19 Surge
description: Monday: A New York Times interactive map shows the uneven toll of the virus, neighborhood by neighborhood, on the nation’s most populous county.
content: (This article is part of the California Today newsletter. Sign up to get it delivered to your inbox.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Chang-rae Lee’s Latest is Fueled by Harrowing Travel, Witness Protection and Food, Food and More Food
description: In “My Year Abroad,” a 20-year-old is scarred by his experiences after meeting a Chinese-American entrepreneur.
content: Chang-rae Lee’s new novel, “My Year Abroad,” is, like everything he writes, considered and elegant, formal and philosophical. He’s firmly in command. He remains in command while this novel runs straight off the road and into a deep ravine. To borrow a euphemism from the world of aeronautics, this long and draggy book is a “controlled flight into terrain.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Tim Ryan, a Top Democrat in Ohio, Is Said to Plan Senate Bid
description: Mr. Ryan, who mounted a long-shot campaign for president in 2019, plans to compete for the state’s open Senate seat. His campaign will test Democrats’ strength in a state tilting to the right.
content: Representative Tim Ryan of Ohio plans to run for his state’s open Senate seat, Democrats who have spoken with him said, a bid that would test whether even a Democrat with roots in the blue-collar Youngstown region and close ties to organized labor can win in the increasingly Republican state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: America Stinks at Video Games?
description: Young video game pros from abroad are being lured to play in the United States.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Chapter 2: The Hunting Lodge
description: “Ellen, have you been trying to get in touch with the royal family of Oudh?” Our reporter receives an invitation to the forest.
content: “Ellen, have you been trying to get in touch with the royal family of Oudh?” Our reporter receives an invitation to the forest.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Jungle Prince, Chapter 3: A House in Yorkshire
description: In a ruined palace in the woods, rummaging through discarded papers, our reporter finds a clue.
content: In a ruined palace in the woods, rummaging through discarded papers, our reporter finds a clue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Egypt?
description: Can you find Egypt on a map? What else do you know about this African nation with 100 million people?
content: Can you find Egypt on a map? What else do you know about this African nation with 100 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Even Jodie Foster Is Still Trying to Figure Jodie Foster Out
description: “A lot of people are made to be an actor on a cellular level. That’s not me.”
content: “A lot of people are made to be an actor on a cellular level. That’s not me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly Couturier
title: Five Yoga Poses You Need to Know
description: You don't need to be a yogi or yogini to reap the benefits of yoga. Here's how to get started.
content: You don't need to be a yogi or yogini to reap the benefits of yoga. Here's how to get started.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $975,000 in California
description: A four-bedroom house with a pool in Rancho Mirage, a farmhouse on five acres in Petaluma and a one-bedroom condominium in San Francisco.
content: A four-bedroom house with a pool in Rancho Mirage, a farmhouse on five acres in Petaluma and a one-bedroom condominium in San Francisco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Biden to Discuss Pandemic Relief Package With Republicans
description: President Biden will meet with 10 Republican senators on Monday who have proposed a much smaller Covid-19 relief package. Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, told reporters that Mr. Biden’s biggest concern is releasing a package that is too small.
content: President Biden will meet with 10 Republican senators on Monday who have proposed a much smaller Covid-19 relief package. Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, told reporters that Mr. Biden’s biggest concern is releasing a package that is too small.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: New York City Wakes Up to Major Snowstorm
description: By early Monday morning, six inches of snow had already fallen in New York City, as officials prepared for widespread power losses and high winds. The winter storm is expected to produce more than a foot of snow in some areas.
content: By early Monday morning, six inches of snow had already fallen in New York City, as officials prepared for widespread power losses and high winds. The winter storm is expected to produce more than a foot of snow in some areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Blackstone and Taylor Turner
title: Powerful Snowstorm Slams Northeast
description: Heavy snow and high winds pounded New York City and surrounding areas, causing dangerous conditions across the region.
content: Heavy snow and high winds pounded New York City and surrounding areas, causing dangerous conditions across the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By NEW YORK CITY MAYOR'S OFFICE
title: N.Y.C. Snowstorm Delays Vaccinations
description: On Monday, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York postponed coronavirus vaccinations to prevent older residents from traveling to appointments in blizzard-like conditions.
content: On Monday, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York postponed coronavirus vaccinations to prevent older residents from traveling to appointments in blizzard-like conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Keegan-Michael Key Will Do Anything for a Laugh
description: His new 10-part podcast, “The History of Sketch Comedy,” is a surprising and earnest defense of a relatively unsung art form.
content: There are people who enjoy comedy, people who are nerdy about comedy and then there is Keegan-Michael Key, an actor and producer whose deep and affectionate connoisseurship of jokes puts him closer to the realm of a jurist or sommelier.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Republicans, Speak Out Against Marjorie Taylor Greene
description: Readers urge Republicans to condemn a member of Congress who has promoted various untrue conspiracy theories and wonder how she ever got elected.
content: To the Editor:

title: Return to School? Teachers Are Being Reasonable
description: Readers, including a teacher, say it’s still not safe. Also: Upset about the Postal Service.
